thread.title: Does the Cubs' search for pitching go through Starlin Castro and Jorge Soler?
thread.title_full: Does the Cubs' search for pitching go through Starlin Castro and Jorge Soler? - Chicago Tribune

author: Steve Rosenbloom
title: Does the Cubs' search for pitching go through Starlin Castro and Jorge Soler?
text:
Jon Lester said the Cubs' terrific young players now know some of what it takes to win in the month where winning is the only acceptable result.
Management knows, too. Management already knew it, even before the Mets pantsed the Cubs in the National League Championship Series.
It’s not just that the Cubs offense finished historically bad with a .164 batting average in getting swept by the Mets. It’s also that the Cubs had no chance of getting through October with a rotation of Lester, Jake Arrieta and Mommy Make It Stop.
Joe Maddon’s post-mortem after the Mets swept the Cubs out of 2015 included a wish list that was topped by starting pitching. No surprise there.
Theo Epstein said adding at least one quality starting pitcher was a priority, either in free agency the way the Cubs came through last winter with Lester or via trade. No surprise there, either.
If you’re really good at the top of your pitching staff and have a versatile batting order that doesn’t rely on just home runs, then you probably can have Jason Hammel or Kyle Hendricks in your playoff rotation, but not both.
Not if you expect to win something big.
Under no circumstances.
Never.
Ever.
That’s a law, I believe, or it will be by the time the Winter Meetings begin.
Speaking of the Winter Meetings, it’s never too early to speculate on the Cubs’ signing free-agent aces David Price or Zack Greinke, or maybe Jeff Samardzija, who has stumbled to the middle of the rotation, although he would be at the bottom if we’re talking Mets staff.
It’s also never too early to talk about bodies to move. Take a bow, Starlin Castro and Jorge Soler.
Castro played well enough the last two months to perhaps bring back a No. 3 starter. Maybe some team still thinks he’s a shortstop. It takes just one team – hello again, Padres? --- and that makes his contract more palatable.
Of the two prominent pieces of Cubs trade bait, I think Castro is more valuable right now than Soler, what with Soler’s regularly scheduled injuries, lousy fielding and fear of October weather.
I mean, if the Mets ever agreed to renew trade talks with the Cubs involving any piece of that young pitching once they lose Yoenis Cespedes and Daniel Murphy to free agency, they’re unlikely to want a guy paralyzed during the most important season of the year.
But again, it just takes one team that hopefully didn’t see him layered up like this was the Iditarod.
Maybe it’s an American League team --- just one team that sees Soler for the designated hitter that he is.
Maybe it’s a warm-weather team. Maybe it’s a dome-team. It takes just one team with major-league-ready arms willing to pay big because it believes it needs Nanook of Right Field.
However it goes, I expect Epstein’s pitch to be better than most of Hammel’s.
